abstract.text: An object that describes a shared record’s metadata.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A share’s metadata is an intermediary object that provides access to the share, its owner, and, for a shared record hierarchy, its root record. Metadata also includes details about the current user’s participation in the share.
You don’t create metadata. CloudKit provides it to your app when the user taps or clicks a share’s
, such as in an email or a message. The method CloudKit calls varies by platform and app configuration, and includes the following:
For a scene-based iOS app in a running or suspended state, CloudKit calls the
method on your window scene delegate.
For a scene-based iOS app that’s not running, the system launches your app in response to the tap or click, and calls the
method on your scene delegate. The
parameter contains the metadata. Use its
property to access it.
For an iOS app that doesn’t use scenes, CloudKit calls your app delegate’s
method.
For a macOS app, CloudKit calls your app delegate’s
method.
For a watchOS app, CloudKit calls the
method on your watch extension delegate.
Respond by checking the
of the provided metadata. If the status is
, use
to accept participation in the share. You can also fetch metadata independent of this flow using
For a shared record hierarchy, the
property contains the ID of the share’s root record. When using
to fetch metadata, you can include the entire root record by setting the operation’s
property to
. CloudKit then populates the
property before it returns the metadata. You can further customize this behavior using the operation’s
property to specify which fields to return. This functionality isn’t applicable for a shared record zone because, unlike a shared record hierarchy, it doesn’t have a nominated root record.

The participant properties provide the current user’s acceptance status, permissions, and role. Use these values to determine what functionality to provide to the user. For example, only display editing controls for accepted participants with
permissions.

abstract.text: Store structured app and user data in iCloud containers that all users of your app can share.
An operation that confirms a user’s participation in a share.
An operation that fetches metadata for one or more shares.
The fields to return when fetching the root record.
A Boolean value that indicates whether to retrieve the root record.
A specialized record type that manages a collection of shared records.
An object that describes a shared record’s metadata.
The ID of the share’s container.
The record ID of the shared hierarchy’s root record.
The identity of the share’s owner.
The share’s permissions for the user who retrieves the metadata.
The share’s participant role for the user who retrieves the metadata.
The share’s participation status for the user who retrieves the metadata.
The share’s participation type for the user who retrieves the metadata.
The share’s root record.
The record ID of the share’s root record.
The share that owns the metadata.
The URL for inviting participants to the share.
Tells the delegate when the user accepts a CloudKit sharing invitation.
Tells the delegate that the app now has access to shared information in CloudKit.
Information about the CloudKit data that’s now available to the app.
Tells the delegate about the addition of a scene to the app.
Tells the delegate that the window scene now has access to shared information in CloudKit.
Tells the delegate that the app has access to shared information in CloudKit.
A true value.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
